TypeSignature.Value: .class public interface auto ansi abstract ODSOFilters implements class Microsoft.Office.Core._IMsoDispObj

Docs.summary: Represents all the filters to apply to the data source attached to the mail merge publication.

remarks.para: The ODSOFilters object is comprised of objects.
Use the method of the ODSOFilters object to add a new filter criterion to the query.
Use the method to access an individual filter criterion.

MemberSignature.Value: public void Add (string Column, Microsoft.Office.Core.MsoFilterComparison Comparison, Microsoft.Office.Core.MsoFilterConjunction Conjunction, string bstrCompareTo = "", bool DeferUpdate = false);

.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Add([in]string Column, [in]valuetype Microsoft.Office.Core.MsoFilterComparison Comparison, [in]valuetype Microsoft.Office.Core.MsoFilterConjunction Conjunction, [in]string bstrCompareTo, [in]bool DeferUpdate) runtime managed
Public Sub Add (Column As String, Comparison As MsoFilterComparison, Conjunction As MsoFilterConjunction, Optional bstrCompareTo As String = "", Optional DeferUpdate As Boolean = false)

Docs.param: Required String. The name of the table in the data source.
Required . How the data in the table is filtered.
Required . Determines how this filter relates to other filters in the ODSOFilters object.
Optional String. If the argument is something other than msoFilterComparisonIsBlank or msoFilterComparisonIsNotBlank, a string to which the data in the table is compared.
Optional Boolean. Default value is False.
Docs.summary: Adds a new filter to the collection.

remarks.para: You can use this property with an Automation object to return that object's container application.

MemberSignature.Value: public int Creator { get; }
.property instance int32 Creator
Public ReadOnly Property Creator As Integer
public: property int Creator { int get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns a 32-bit integer that indicates the application in which the specified object was created.

remarks.para: If the specified object was created in Microsoft Word, this property returns 1297307460, which represents the string MSWD; if created in Microsoft Excel, this property returns 1480803660. This value can also be represented by the constant wdCreatorCode in Word, or xlCreatorCode in Excel.

The Creator property was primarily designed to be used on the Macintosh, where each application has a four-character creator code. For example, Microsoft Word has the creator code MSWD. For additional information about this property, consult the language reference Help included with Microsoft Office Macintosh Edition.

The Creator property always returns the numeric identifier for the active application, just as the property always returns the name of the active application in string form. Use the CreatedBy property of the , , , and objects to return the name of the individual who created those objects. Use document properties to return information about the authors of Office documents.
